text: <@U8442MDS6> Thanks for all your work on the astro libraries, especially SPICE.jl has been super useful for me. I've been working on a (still quite limited) trajectory propagation library (<https://github.com/dpad/OrbitalTrajectories.jl>), probably nothing new for you but might have some useful things here or there (for example, I dynamically download SPICE kernels as Julia artifacts when the user first asks for a specific body).

attachments.title: jsOrrery - Solar System Simulator
attachments.text: See the Solar System in your browser with jsOrrery, a Javascript / WebGL orbital mechanics simulator.

elements.text: That package looks interesting. I suppose it could calculate this?
http://mgvez.github.io/jsorrery/

text: I made a small trial of using the Python package, and it didn’t feel right. OTOH, its documentationhelps with SPICE.

elements.text: I made a small trial of using the Python package, and it didn’t feel right. OTOH, its documentationhelps with SPICE.

text: The jsOrrery has the best solar system visualisation I’ve seen.

elements.text: The jsOrrery has the best solar system visualisation I’ve seen.

text: <@U01CQTKB86N> If you meant OrbitalTrajectories.jl, then kind of. It depends on what you want to simulate. My package doesn't do N-body simulation per-se, what it does is simulate a single spacecraft (i.e. something of negligible mass) given the actual known positions of the solar system bodies you pick. These positions come from the SPICE ephemerides, so the propagation is known as an Ephemeris Restricted N-Body Problem -- you're only actually simulating a single body, but taking into account the real positions of all the N other bodies. It doesn't really do visualisations like that though.

elements.text: If you meant OrbitalTrajectories.jl, then kind of. It depends on what you want to simulate. My package doesn't do N-body simulation per-se, what it does is simulate a single spacecraft (i.e. something of negligible mass) given the actual known positions of the solar system bodies you pick. These positions come from the SPICE ephemerides, so the propagation is known as an Ephemeris Restricted N-Body Problem -- you're only actually simulating a single body, but taking into account the real positions of all the N other bodies. It doesn't really do visualisations like that though.

text: If instead of having known positions of the planets, you wanted to "create" a solar system, i.e. simulate all the planets themselves, then you need a proper N-body simulator.

elements.text: If instead of having known positions of the planets, you wanted to "create" a solar system, i.e. simulate all the planets themselves, then you need a proper N-body simulator.

text: Regarding jsOrrery, having a quick read through its "Credits" -- it seems they're not using the positions given by ephemerides like SPICE, but rather calculating (highly accurate but still approximate) positions given orbital elements. Seems their Earth and Moon positions use even higher accuracy models.

elements.text: Regarding jsOrrery, having a quick read through its "Credits" -- it seems they're not using the positions given by ephemerides like SPICE, but rather calculating (highly accurate but still approximate) positions given orbital elements. Seems their Earth and Moon positions use even higher accuracy models.

text: I guess.. I’m not interested in the implementation of jsOrrery. The three.js it uses is an odd beast. It is a visualisation tool and a generic(ish) lib. For instance here is a 3x3 matrix multiplication class. <https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/en/math/Matrix3|https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/en/math/Matrix3>

text: Does OrbitalTrajectories.jl have something that can get me, for instance for Mars, the x,y,z coordinates and dx,dy,dz velocities at time t, in terms of of a Sun based reference frame? I think this is also pretty simple with SPICE, but I didn’t quite figure out all the small details.

elements.text: Does OrbitalTrajectories.jl have something that can get me, for instance for Mars, the x,y,z coordinates and dx,dy,dz velocities at time t, in terms of of a Sun based reference frame? I think this is also pretty simple with SPICE, but I didn’t quite figure out all the small details.

text: Thanks <@U8442MDS6>, and likewise!

elements.text: Thanks
, and likewise!

text: <@U01CQTKB86N> Yes this is something we get directly from SPICE. If you have a look at <https://github.com/dpad/OrbitalTrajectories.jl/blob/master/src/SPICE/spice.jl>, this should help you. Specifically, the `get_state` function just calls the SPICE.jl's `spkezr` function directly, which gives you the state (position + velocity) of a body relative to some reference.

elements.text: Yes this is something we get directly from SPICE. If you have a look at
, this should help you. Specifically, the
get_state
function just calls the SPICE.jl's
spkezr
function directly, which gives you the state (position + velocity) of a body relative to some reference.

text: The main thing to know to use SPICE is that you need to first load the appropriate kernels (i.e. download kernel data files from the SPICE website, have a look at <https://github.com/dpad/OrbitalTrajectories.jl/blob/master/deps/build.jl> for the default kernels I download -- you probably would only need the "default" kernel which includes all the planet systems, and maybe the "meta" kernels). Then you load them with SPICE by just calling `furnsh` on the file location, and then you can uses the SPICE functions like `spkezr` to get you the state of a body.

elements.text: The main thing to know to use SPICE is that you need to first load the appropriate kernels (i.e. download kernel data files from the SPICE website, have a look at

for the default kernels I download -- you probably would only need the "default" kernel which includes all the planet systems, and maybe the "meta" kernels). Then you load them with SPICE by just calling
furnsh
on the file location, and then you can uses the SPICE functions like
spkezr
to get you the state of a body.
